description_html:
Set in the seaside town of Torquay on the English Riviera, the British sitcom Fawlty Towers ran for just two seasons of six episodes each, in 1975 and 1979.

The show stars Monty Python's John Cleese, who wrote it with his wife (from 1968-1978) and Fawlty Towers co-star Connie Booth. The British Film Institute (BFI) ranked the show number 1 on the list of top 100 TV shows it compiled in 2000.

John Cleese got the idea for the show after he, Eric Idle, and other members of the Monty Python troupe stayed at the Gleneagles Hotel in Torquay while filming Monty Python. He based Fawlty Towers' owner and main character, Basil Fawlty, on Donald Sinclair, who was the owner of the hotel at the time of their visit.
story_html:
Filmed in front of a live audience, Fawlty Towers is a farce and full of both British and physical humour. Like most things in life, this sort of humour is not for everyone.

These spiritual portraits show that the characters on the show form a small team of diverse, interdependent individuals. Nothing would please me more than to learn these images inspired someone who believes they do not care for this type of humour to give it another chance.

You can find many of the episodes online on youtube. A few of the best ones are Gourmet Night, The Germans, The Kipper and the Corpse, and Basil the Rat.

Moreover, if you give Fawlty Towers a chance and still do not care for British and physical humour, at least you can say you tried your best to appreciate the teamwork portrayed in the most highly regarded and critically acclaimed of these shows.

image_list.story_intro_html: The manager of Fawlty Towers is Basil Fawlty. He may be the one in charge, but ....
image_list.story_html:
The manager of Fawlty Towers is Basil Fawlty. He may be the one in charge, but he is definitely not the one who is in control.

Basil Fawlty: Yellow and Blue, and Green

The Yellow and Blue in Basil's spiritual portrait show he is open experiences and ideas, and the Green shows he has a preference for logic over emotion. His perceptive, logical mind is always working, so he has ambitions and likes coming up with schemes.

However, compared to his wife Sybil Fawlty, he is — like just about everyone else — relatively indecisive. She takes total advantage of his relative indecisiveness and makes it clear to him how he is supposed to behave. The end result is, as the manager he is ostensibly free to do things any way he wants, but ultimately his every action is motivated by fear of his domineering, nagging wife.

Thus, much of the farcical nature of the show is based on Basil pursuing some scheme or another that Sybil doesn't approve of. He frequently enlists Polly's and Manuel's help in building a mountain of lies around his misconduct — and hilarity always ensues!

Basil the Realist

Played by John Cleese, who created and co-wrote the series, deep down Basil is a realist. The following quote follows a brief period of elation he feels upon finally getting one over on a difficult guest:

Sybil: Basil, sometimes....
Basil: [Puts his hand on her side, in an extremely rare showing of affection.] Seriously, Sybil, do you remember when we were first manacled together? We used to laugh quite a lot.
Sybil: [Removes his hand and leaves the room.] Yes, but not at the same time, Basil.
Basil: That's true. That was a warning, I guess. Should have spotted that, shouldn't I?
  Zoom! What was that?
  That was your life, mate.
  Oh, that was quick. Do I get another?
  Sorry, mate, that's your lot.
 — Basil Fawlty, Season 2, Episode 1, Communication Problems

Basil's bleak outlook explains why he runs, as Cleese puts it in the commentary for The Kipper and the Corpse, a hotel run for the convenience of the staff.

Basil and Team Fawlty

These spiritual portraits show that the management and staff at Fawlty Towers comprise a team of fairly diverse, interdependent individuals.

Basil is the manager of the team, and his image is the only one with a Green line in it, showing he prefers logic over emotion, so he is well-suited for this role. However, his wife is much more decisive than he — and most everyone else in the world — is, so she winds up being the real boss.

The disconnect between Basil's presumed role as manager and his actual role as Sybil's henpecked husband is one of the main sources of humour in Fawlty Towers. He can manage his need to be open and try new things — the Yellow and Blue in his image — for only just so long before he starts to chafe at being tied down and under Sybil's complete control.

Basil's most distinctive quality on this team is his objectivity — represented by the Green in his spiritual portrait — but his most salient quality is his openness, and this openness ends up taking precedence. His need to break free causes him to fall prey to Sybil's domineering manner, which in turn makes him emotional to the point of being manic.

Although the end result is Basil becomes more of a burden on the team than a productive member of it, without Mr. Fawlty there would be no Fawlty Towers. Despite the challenges, he manages to get the job done — given the essential help of two of the other team members, and despite the overbearing help of his wife.

Once we learn how to interpret these spiritual portraits, we can look at the members of a team and see how it really works — or doesn't work — regardless of the superficial titles and presumed roles of its members.

Because it is small, interdependent, and diverse, the team at Fawlty Towers is very fragile. Losing even just one member would cause the fictional hotel, the real show, or both to lose their effectiveness and even fall apart.

These spiritual portraits give us insight into how this team works together, and could even help in repairing it, if one of the members was to leave.

image_list.story_intro_html: In the Fawlty Towers hotel, Basil's wife Sybil Fawlty is undeniably ....
image_list.story_html:
In the Fawlty Towers hotel, Basil's wife Sybil Fawlty is undeniably the boss.

Sybil Fawlty: Red and Green, and Yellow

The Red and Green in Sybil's spiritual portrait shows she is decisive, and the Yellow — along with the almost total lack of any Blue whatsoever — shows she is interested only in facts.

And indeed she can be extremely closed-minded, especially when it comes to Basil's dreams of getting ahead in some way. There's never any hesitation in her voice, and it's like all of life's issues are already decided and everything is a done deal.

The Indomitable Sybil Fawlty

Actress Prunella Scales plays this role perfectly. Her formal manner and impeccable dress — down to the way she does her makeup and is always fussing with her hair and nails — contrasts strongly with Basil's farcical behavior, that tends to be increasingly manic as each episode progresses.

One of her funniest lines is a short and simple one, spoken frequently and repeatedly on the phone to her elusive friend Audrey:

Oh I know. I know!
 — Sybil Fawlty on Fawlty Towers, multiple episodes.

And indeed, this sums up her personality quite well, because if anyone in the Fawlty Towers hotel knows anything, it's Sybil Fawlty!

Sybil and the Team at Fawlty Towers

These spiritual portraits show that the management and staff at Fawlty Towers comprise a team of fairly diverse, interdependent individuals.

Sybil is Basil's wife, and her role is to support him in his position as manager. However, because her personality is so much more decisive than his — and most everyone else's — in reality her role turns out to be entirely dictatorial.

Sybil's need for nearly complete control over her husband — evidenced by the overwhelming amount of Red and Green in her image — is one of the main sources of humour in Fawlty Towers. The adjective nearly is essential here, because without at least a ray of hope, Basil would surely suffocate and die.

Sybil's most salient and distinctive quality on this team is her decisiveness, represented by the Red and Green in her spiritual portrait. Without her running things, albeit mostly through Basil, it's conceivable that nothing would get done — at least not properly.

Without Sybil, the entire team would be at risk of total failure, and without a new member — someone to provide the decisiveness that is lacking in the other members — to guide it, Fawlty Towers would surely go out of business, quickly and completely.

Once we learn how to interpret these spiritual portraits, we can look at the members of a team and see how it really works — or doesn't work — regardless of the superficial titles and presumed roles of its members.

Because it is small, interdependent, and diverse, the team at Fawlty Towers is very fragile. Losing even just one member would cause the fictional hotel, the real show, or both to lose their effectiveness and even fall apart.

These spiritual portraits give us insight into how this team works together, and could even help in repairing it, if one of the members was to leave.

image_list.story_intro_html: In the Fawlty Towers universe, Polly Sherman is the most ....
image_list.story_html:
In the Fawlty Towers universe, Polly Sherman is the most reasonable, sane one.

Polly Sherman: Blue and Red

The Blue shows Polly has insight and — when combined with the Red the image — shows she has empathy for others. This enables her to help Basil, during his frequent periods of crisis, to prolong his schemes and deceptions.

And her ability to help Basil dig himself deeper and deeper into his deceptions, in turn, extends the farcical nature of the show. This ultimately serves to continue the build-up of tension until the final punch line or other resolution.

The Incredibly Versatile Polly Sherman

Played by Connie Booth — who co-wrote the series with John Cleese — Polly performs a wide variety of duties in the hotel:

Waitress? That's a joke! I help out at reception, I clean the rooms, I deal with the tradesmen, I man the switchboard, I change the fuses, and if you think my duties now include impersonating members of your family, you have got one more screw loose than I thought!
 — Polly Sherman on Fawlty Towers, Season 2, Episode 5, The Anniversary.

Polly is kind-hearted, but she has a mercenary side as well. So — minor spoiler alert — in this case she ends up fulfilling Basil's request to impersonate a family member, and it turns out to be one of the funniest scenes in the series!

Polly and Team Fawlty

These spiritual portraits show that the management and staff at Fawlty Towers comprise a team of fairly diverse, interdependent individuals.

Polly is the maid and her colorful image shows she has the flexibility to perform the many other duties that fall to her. As an art student who works directly for Basil, her loyalty is to him, and their personalities compliment one another quite well.

Polly's role as the sane one and her excellent communication skills contribute greatly to the humour in Fawlty Towers. Her image is the only one of the team members' images to have a Blue line, and she almost never hesitates to put her intuition and communication skills to use in helping Basil pursue his dreams — no matter how ridiculous they are.

Polly's most salient and distinctive quality on this team is her idealism, represented by the Blue in her spiritual portrait. Ostensibly a manual job, it turns out her duties are challenging both emotionally and intellectually — and Polly proves herself uniquely qualified for the role.

Without Polly's idealism to serve as the team's glue, it would surely disintegrate. Each team member would quickly go their separate way, citing irreconilable differences and saying things like Pfft (Manuel), Wicked (Basil), and I never (Sybil).

Once we learn how to interpret these spiritual portraits, we can look at the members of a team and see how it really works — or doesn't work — regardless of the superficial titles and presumed roles of its members.

Because it is small, interdependent, and diverse, the team at Fawlty Towers is very fragile. Losing even just one member would cause the fictional hotel, the real show, or both to lose their effectiveness and even fall apart.

These spiritual portraits give us insight into how this team works together, and could even help in repairing it, if one of the members was to leave.

image_list.story_html:
In the Fawlty Towers heirarchy, Manuel is the low man on the totem pole. His desire to be successful in his new home — He's from Barcelona — overrides everything else in his life, and Basil in particular takes full advantage of this.

Manuel: Yellow and Blue, and Red

The Yellow and Blue in Manuel's spiritual portrait show he is open to new experiences and ideas, and the Red shows he is passionate and amiable, even cooperative.

It's good he's willing to cooperate because his job requires him to be obedient while everyone else bosses him around.

The Well-Meaning Manuel

Actor Andrew Sachs is excellent in this role. He puts up with a lot of physical abuse and was even injured twice: in one episode John Cleese accidentally hits him with a real frying pan instead of a fake one, and in another he suffered second degree burns.

Manuel's being Spanish — and especially his difficulty with the English language — is constantly adding to the farcical aspect of the show.

Basil Fawlty: There's too much butter [points three times, once for each word] on those trays.
Manuel: No no no. [Points three times, one time per word, just as Basil did.] Uno dos tres!
 — Fawlty Towers, Season 1, Episode 1, A Touch of Class.

The fact that Polly can communicate with him supports her role as being the sane one.

Manuel and Team Fawlty

These spiritual portraits show that the management and staff at Fawlty Towers comprise a team of fairly diverse, interdependent individuals.

Manuel is the waiter in the hotel's restarant, but he frequently also serves as a porter. His image shows he is friendly and down-to-earth, and he is happy to perform any task his boss Basil asks him to do.

Manuel's dedication to Basil, and his willingness to put up with all sorts of physical abuse from him, is the main source of the physical humour in Fawlty Towers. A character with less openness — and with less Yellow and Blue in their portrait — would quickly leave this position for another.

Manuel may be the low man on the Fawlty Towers totem pole, but he plays an important role. He's dedicated, hard working, and his character is very likeable, relatable, and even endearing.

Without Manuel the entire team would suffer, and Basil would suffer the most. With a suitable replacement, Fawlty Towers the hotel would survive the loss, but Fawlty Towers the show most certainly would not.

Once we learn how to interpret these spiritual portraits, we can look at the members of a team and see how it really works — or doesn't work — regardless of the superficial titles and presumed roles of its members.

Because it is small, interdependent, and diverse, the team at Fawlty Towers is very fragile. Losing even just one member would cause the fictional hotel, the real show, or both to lose their effectiveness and even fall apart.

These spiritual portraits give us insight into how this team works together, and could even help in repairing it, if one of the members was to leave.
